Fig. 1 Small-angle XRD patterns of KIT-6 and K-xAl catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of KIT-6 (A, B) and K-4Al (C, D) catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of KIT-6 (A, B) and K-4Al (C, D) catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (A) and pore size distribution of KIT-6 and K-xAl catalysts (B). Fig 4 Fig. 5 27Al NMR spectra of K-2Al, K-4Al and K-5Al catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Pyridine FTIR spectra of K-3Al, K-4Al and K-5Al catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 NH3-TPD profiles of K-2Al, K-4Al and K-5Al catalysts. Fig 7 Fig. 8 GVL conversion and butene yield over K-xAl catalysts at 300 °C. *Reaction conditions: GVL (1 g), catalysts (0.1 g), N2 (atmospheric pressure), reaction time (4 h). Fig 8 Fig. 9 Effects of different reaction conditions on GVL decarboxylation reaction over the K-xAl catalyst: (A) reaction temperature, (B) reaction time, (C) catalyst content. *If not specified, the default reaction conditions were as follows: 0.1 g catalyst, 1.0 g GVL, N2 pressure: atmospheric pressure, reaction time: 4 h, reaction temperature: 300 °C. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Ln n as a function for the reaction time over K-4Al catalyst at different reaction temperatures (A), and Arrhenius plots of ln k based on different temperatures (B). Fig 10 Fig. 11 Recyclability test of the K-4Al catalyst at 320 °C. *Reaction condition: weight of the catalyst 0.1 g, weight of GVL 1 g, N2 pressure: atmospheric pressure, reaction time: 4 h. After each cycle, the catalyst is calcined at 600 °C for 1 h under the air flow. Fig 11 Fig. 12 TEM image (A) and NH3-TPD profile (B) of spent K-4Al catalyst (after 3nd cycle test). Fig 12 Table 1 Textural structure parameters of KIT-6 and K-xAl catalysts. This work aimed at elucidating the beneficial effect of the solid-phase grinding method on the catalytic performance of K-xAl for catalyzing γ-valerolactone to butene. Research indicated that a part of Al species was successfully introduced into the framework of KIT-6 support without destroying its original ordered mesoporous structure by the solid-phase grinding treatment method. Hence, Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were formed on the surface of the catalyst. By adjusting the amount of Al species, the content of weak acid sites (100-300 °C) on the catalyst surface can reach as much as 0.31 mmol·g−1. Through the catalytic activity tested, the K-4Al catalyst exhibited optimum catalytic performance. The GVL conversion rate and butene yield can reach 96.2% and 90.1% at 300 °C, respectively. In addition, the K-4Al catalyst also showed satisfactory renewable performance in cycle tests. These findings will provide useful guidelines for further catalyst design for the preparation of butene from γ-valerolactone. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Butene γ-valerolactone Solid acid catalyst Solid-phase grinding Fast synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass energy is a renewable source of carbon with the advantages of being carbon neutral, low in sulfur, and high in hydrogen content, which can replace fossil energy and other chemical raw materials [1–3]. Biomass-derived γ-valerolactone (GVL) is known as the potential biomass energy source, it can be easily obtained from catalytic hydrogenation of levulinic acid (come from the catalytic conversion of lignocellulose) [4–6]. Butene is an extremely important chemical raw material, its production process mainly depended on the catalytic cracking of primary energy [7,8]. This butene production method is not only complicated in the production process but also over-relies on chemical energy, causing serious environment pollution [9]. Based on the above facts, the study of biomass-derived γ-valerolactone replacing traditional fossil energy sources to produce butene in a two-step reaction has attracted many researchers’ attention [10–14]. As a result, it is of great significance to design and synthesize a green catalyst for the preparation of butene from γ-valerolactone. In 2010, Dumesic's group [15] at the University of Wisconsin first proposed the idea of using biomass energy source γ-valerolactone to produce renewable fuels. Under the condition of 375 °C and 36 bar, GVL aqueous solution could be decarboxylated by SiO2/Al2O3 to produce equimolar butene and carbon dioxide without adding an external hydrogen source. In May of the following year, they provided a preliminary explanation of the mechanism of GVL decarboxylation, suggesting that the pentenoic acid is an intermediate product in the ring opening and decarboxylation of GVL. In 2014, Kellicutt et al. [16] demonstrated that the Brønsted acid sites played an important role in the decarboxylation of GVL by comparing the performance of microporous MFI molecular sieves, amorphous mesoporous alumina ASA, γ-Al2O3, and silicon dioxide (PWA) loaded with phosphotungstic acid under certain reaction conditions to catalyze the GVL decarboxylation. In 2015, Zhang and co-workers [11,17] synthesized mesoporous SiO2/Al2O3 by sol-gel method to catalyze the GVL decarboxylation to butene. A good yield of 97% was achieved at the temperature of 350 °C over this catalyst. In 2016, Bond et al. [18] analyzed catalytic active trends over amorphous silica alumina (ASA), generating a set of meaningful fundamental kinetic and thermodynamic parameters, while again verifying that the fundamental steps of the reaction occur in parallel at surface Brønsted sites. In 2020, Lin et al. [19] introduced two metals, niobium and aluminum, into the HZSM-5 molecular sieve to obtain a new NbAlS-1 catalyst. A continuous passage of 30% aqueous GVL solution through NbAlS-1 at 300 °C and atmospheric pressure resulted in a 99% butene yield. In the same year, Wang et al. [10] synthesized an amorphous SiO2-Al2O3(Si/Al=4:1) catalyst for the GVL decarboxylation reaction. In their work, the reaction pathway was also explored. They found that due to the presence of carbon-based electron acceptors, the inner ring of the GVL molecule was readily excited and opened to form the protonated γ-protonated pentenoic acid (γ-PEA) which was then converted into the five isomers of PEA via H-shift. The carbon-carbon single bond between the α-carbon and carbonyl carbon on the γ-PEA was then cleaved by the combined action of the acid sites to produce butene and carbon dioxide. Since 2020, our group [20,21] has been committed to the research of catalytic GVL decarboxylation to butene. We employed aluminum-containing ordered mesoporous molecular sieves as the catalyst catalyzing GVL to butene for the first time and obtained good catalytic performance. The 2.23wt%Al-SBA-15 catalyst prepared by impregnation could obtain a high butene yield of 86.4% under the reaction conditions of 320 °C, 4 h, and 10 wt.% catalyst dosage. Compared with SBA-15, the ordered three-dimensional mesoporous silicon dioxide KIT-6 possesses a bicon-tinuous cubic structure of Ia3d symmetry and interpenetrating cylindrical pore system, which greatly improves the efficiency of molecular transport. Hence, it always is employed as the support of adsorbents and catalysts [22,23]. Based on this unique mesoporous pore structure, KIT-6 was selected as the catalyst support to prepare aluminum-modified KIT-6 catalyst in our subsequent research [21]. Compared with 2.23wt%Al-SBA-15, the GVL conversion and butene yield over the 3wt%Al-KIT-6 could be up to 99.68% and 94.28% at 300 °C. More importantly, 3wt%Al-KIT-6 also exhibited more outstanding regenerable performance for cycle tests. In the above studies, we also investigated the catalytic mechanism of the reaction [20,21]. It was found that the decarboxylation of γ-PEA obtained from the ring opening of GVL controlled the whole reaction speed, and the suitable Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio, a large number of weak acid sites played a major role to improve catalytic performance. Solid-phase grinding method, as a simple post-synthesis method, effectively avoided the competitive adsorption of solvents and could achieve the original intention of green synthesis. Muhammad Yaseen et al. devised a simple grinding strategy to insert the La(NO3)3 precursor directly between the silicon wall and the template sandwiched in KIT-6, which greatly increased the dispersion of La2O3 [24]. Wang et al. demonstrated that the solid-phase grinding method could effectively incorporate metallic species into the channels of ordered mesoporous materials with stronger metal support interactions compared to the conventional wet immersion method [25]. In this study, a series of KIT-6 based K-xAl catalysts with different aluminum contents were designed and synthesized by the simple solid-phase grinding method with high energy efficiency and high γ-valerolactone decarboxylation efficiency as the main objective. The prepared catalysts were characterized in terms of their physical phase, microstructure, pore structure, and surface acidity. The reaction conditions were also optimized, and the catalytic performance was thoroughly evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All materials used in the experimental process were AR grade and required no further treatment for use. Polyionic PEO20-PPO70-PEO20 (P123 with Mw=5800) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich (USA), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS), aluminum chloride (AlCl3), hydrochloric acid (37 wt%, noted as conc. hydrochloric acid), anhydrous ethanol and n-butanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co.. γ-Valerolactone (GVL, >98%) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Distilled water was self-made by the laboratory. 2.2 Preparation of K-xAl catalysts The KIT-6 was prepared by hydrothermal method. Using TEOS as the silicon source, the specific synthesis process refers to previous studies [26,27]. The K-xAl catalyst was prepared by the simple solid-phase grinding method. The aluminum chloride (AlCl3) was first ground manually into fine powder in an agate mortar, followed by the addition of KIT-6 (0.300 g). The mixture of KIT-6 and AlCl3 was then continued to ground manually at atmospheric temperature for 30 min, with the grinding speed evenly maintained at about two revolutions per second (clockwise). Finally, it was calcined in air at 550 °C for 5 h. According to the percentage of the mass of aluminum atoms to the KIT-6 matrix, the obtained catalyst was named as K-xAl, where x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 wt.%, “K” represents the KIT-6 and “Al” represents the Al species in the catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The experimental procedure and conditions for catalyst characterization were consistent with those reported in our previous studies [20,21]. Including XRD, SEM, TEM, Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, 27Al solid-state NMR, Pyridine adsorption FTIR (Py-FTIR) and NH3-TPD. Specifically, Py-FTIR was performed on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrometer. Self-supported wafers of 20 ± 0.5 mg (d = 11 mm) uniform thickness were put in a quartz IR cell equipped with a CaF2 window. The tests were performed by pretreatment with nitrogen at 300 °C for 30 min. After cooling to 30 °C, the sample wafers were passed through pyridine vapor and pyridine was adsorbed for 30 min. Then the sample was warmed up to 100 °C and evacuated, and the spectra were collected at wavelengths of 4000 ∼ 400 cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic activity testing The catalytic activity test referred to the methods reported in our previous studies [20,21]. First, a certain amount of the catalyst (0.000 - 0.140 g) and 1.000 g γ-valerolactone were added into the stainless steel batch-stirred tank reactor and mixed well. After sealing the reactor, high purity N2 was introduced into the reactor to remove impurity gases from the system, such as O2 and CO2. Subsequently, the tank reactor was transferred into the casing heater. The temperature was heated to the desired temperature (280 - 320 °C) and maintained for the desired test reaction time (0–4 h) under the continued stirring (700 rpm·min−1). After the reaction was completed, the reactor was transferred to a cold-water stream and cooled to room temperature. The liquid products were dissolved in cyclohexane firstly, and analyzed by the GC-MS (Trace DSQ-Polaris Q, DB-5MS column, 30 m). The analysis conditions were described as follows: nitrogen as carrier gas (1.2 mL·min−1), inlet temperature was 250 °C, and detector temperature was 300 °C. The temperature program for GC analysis was: initial column temperature 30 °C, hold for 5 min, 5 °C·min−1 to 60 °C and hold for 1 min, then 10 °C·min−1 to 260 °C and hold for 5 min. The gas products were collected with a gas storage bag and qualitatively analyzed by GC (Varian 3800, Porapak Q column, TCD detector). The analysis conditions were described as follows: Ar as carrier gas (25 mL·min−1), inlet temperature was 50 °C, detector temperature was 100 °C, column temperature was 50 °C, and the detector bridge current was 80 mA. In this reaction, the consumption of one mole of GVL produced one mol butene and one mole of CO2. Although by-produces were inevitably formed during the reaction, they are all in the form of liquids (> C5) [21]. It means that the butene and CO2 were only two gas products in the whole reaction. Hence, the butene yield ( Y (C4)%) and the GVL conversions ( Conv. %) were calculated from the following formula according to the mass conservation [12,20,21]. (1) Y ( C 4 ) % = n ( a c t u a l b u t e n e o u t p u t ) n ( t h e o r e t i c a l b u t e n e o u t p u t ) = ( m 0 − m 1 ) / M G V L m 0 / M G V L = 100.12 · ( m 0 − m 1 ) 100.12 · m 0 × 100 % (2) C o n v . % = ( m 0 − m 2 ) m 0 × 100 % Where m 0 (g) represents the mass of GVL that initial input, m 1 (g) represents the total mass of all the liquids that remained in the tank reactor after the reaction. m 2 (g) represents the mass of the GVL that remained in the liquid product after the reaction, which was calculated according to the data of GC analysis (external standard method), MGVL represents the relative molecular mass of GVL. In the evaluation of the catalyst regeneration cycle, the used catalyst was fully dried at 60 °C for 4 h, then calcined at 600 °C for 1 h for activation. Finally, the activated catalyst was ground evenly and then bagged for the next test. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural structural features The order mesoporous structure of K-xAl catalysts was analyzed by small-angle XRD characterization firstly. As shown in the Fig. 1 , both the synthesized KIT-6 and K-xAl catalysts showed an obvious diffraction peak at around 2θ = 0.9°, which belonged to the (211) plane of bicontinuous cubic space group Ia3d symmetry [28,29]. It indicated that the synthesized catalysts had an ordered mesoporous structure, and the process of introducing Al into the KIT-6 matrix by a simple solid-phase grinding method did not destroy the original order mesopores of KIT-6. In addition, compared with KIT-6, the diffraction peaks corresponding to the (211) plane of the K-xAl catalysts slightly shifted to higher angles, which could be attributed to the contraction of the unit cell [30,31]. The unit cell parameter (a0) of the (211) plane for the KIT-6 support was calculated to be 22.54 nm as shown in the Table 1 , which was bigger than that of all K-xAl catalysts. All above results implied that a certain amount of Al species can be introduced into the KIT-6 framework by a facile solid-phase grinding method without destroying the intrinsic structure of KIT-6 [30], which provided a suitable structure environment for the generation of the solid acid sites on the K-xAl catalysts. To further determine the textural structural features of the K-xAl catalysts, the KIT-6 and K-4Al were selected and observed by SEM and TEM, respectively. As shown in the SEM images (Fig. 2 ), it can be found that both KIT-6 and K-4Al catalysts were irregularly gravelly and highly dispersed, generally less than 10 μm in size, which was conducive to improve mass transfer efficiency [32]. No noticeable differences can be found from the micromorphology of these two catalysts. For mesoporous materials, the ordered pore structure was essential for their excellent catalytic activity. Thus, the higher resolution TEM was used to observe the internal pore structure changes of KIT-6 and K-4Al catalysts. From the Fig. 3 (A) and (B), it can be seen that the pore channel continuity of KIT-6 was excellent and highly ordered with a uniform pore size of 5 ∼ 6 nm, which was in accordance with that reported in the previous study [33]. For the K-4Al catalyst, the well-ordered mesoporous structure can also be observed in the Fig. 3(C) and (D). The only difference was that the pore wall of K-4Al was slightly thicker than that of KIT-6 in the observed region, as shown in the Fig. 3(B) and (D). The above results indicated that the mesoporous structure of the K-4Al catalyst was preserved after doping with Al elements by solid-phase grinding. Moreover, it can be speculated that some Al species had entered the framework of KIT-6, while others dispersed on the catalyst surface without serious aggregation. In order to explore the changes in the pore structure of KIT-6 and K-xAl catalysts more deeply, nitrogen adsorption-desorption test was performed and the results were shown in the Fig. 4 and Table 1. From the Fig. 4(A), it can be found that all isotherms of tested catalysts had distinct capillary condensation steps and H1 hysteresis loops at high relative pressures, which can be classified as the type IV pore structure [34]. The pore size of all samples was distributed in a narrow range of 4 ∼ 7 nm as exhibited in the Fig. 4(B), which corresponded to the small-angle XRD results, verifying that the ordered mesoporous structure of the material was not destroyed when Al species were introduced by the solid-phase grinding method. However, it also can be found that although the main pore diameter calculated from the adsorption branch of the isotherm using the BJH method was 5.6 nm for all the catalysts, the pore that diameter located at ∼5 nm occupied a certain percentage for K-xAl catalysts compared with KIT-6. It indicated that Al species entered the tunnel of KIT-6 by the solid-phase grinding method, which was in accordance with the phenomenon observed by TEM. The detailed textural structure parameters of KIT-6 and K-xAl catalysts were shown in the Table 1. The BET surface area and pore volume of KIT-6 were 813.52 m2·g−1 and 1.14 m3·g−1, respectively. The high BET surface area and pore volume provided sufficient space conditions for Al species doping. The BET surface area of the K-xAl catalysts decreased gradually with the increase of the Al doping amount. The specific surface areas of K-1Al, K-4Al and K-5Al were reduced to 670.55 m2·g−1, 635.27 m2·g−1 and 610.37 m2·g−1, respectively. Correspondingly, the pore volume also tended to decrease gradually, but even at 5 wt.% Al loading, the catalyst still maintained a higher specific surface area and a larger pore volume. The introduction of Al species by solid-phase grinding method did not have much effect on the textural structure of the KIT-6. To clearly elucidate the present situation of Al species in the K-xAl catalysts, 27Al NMR was performed [31,35]. Fig. 5 showed the 27Al NMR spectra of K-2Al, K-4Al and K-5Al catalysts, respectively. It can be observed that the K-xAl catalysts had three main resonance peaks at chemical shifts of 0, 33 and 54 ppm. The resonance peak at 54 ppm appeared due to the tetra-coordination of aluminum species into the matrix framework to form a tetrahedral AlO4 structural unit, while the 0 ppm corresponded to a six-coordinated aluminum species outside the catalyst framework (octahedral AlO6 structural unit), and the 33 ppm also corresponded to a distorted five-coordinated aluminum species outside the framework [30,36,37]. From the 27AlNMR spectra of K-2Al, two major resonance peaks at chemical shifts of 0 ppm and 54 ppm, and a less pronounced resonance peak at 33 ppm were observed [11]. It indicated that the Al species introduced by the solid-phase grinding method were distributed both inside and outside the framework of KIT-6. When the aluminum content increased from 2 wt.% to 4 wt.%, the three resonance peaks located were significantly enhanced, especially for the peak at 33 ppm. It indicated that with the increase of tetrahedral AlO4 structural unit in the framework of KIT-6, the increase in extra-framework Al species was inevitable at the same time, and the proportion of extra-framework Al species was also increased. The resonance peaks at 0 ppm and 33 ppm were further enhanced when the Al content kept increasing up to 5 wt.% and most of the Al species were present outside the framework. With the excessive introduction of Al species, more and more Al species would like to accumulate on the surface of KIT-6, which was also consistent with the results of the nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis. As a consequence, the incorporated Al species could produce the maximum number of acid sites only if a suitable Al content was introduced. Based on the above results, it was believed that Al species can be successfully introduced into the KIT-6 framework through a simple and green solid-phase grinding method. Most importantly the Al species that did not enter into the framework only blocked a small part of the pores, resulting in a very limited reduction of the specific surface area. 3.2 Surface acid properties The main purpose of introducing Al species into the KIT-6 framework and surface was to create sufficient Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst's surface as the actives for the reaction. As depicted in the Fig. 5, the Al species in the framework of KIT-6 tended to produce Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites, while the Al species outside the framework only provided Lewis acid sites. Hence, in this section, the Py-FTIR was performed to detect the presence and quantitative variation of acid types of K-xAl catalysts, and the results were shown in the Fig. 6 . From the figure, it can be seen that the three catalysts with different Al content all showed three distinct pyridine adsorption peaks in the range of 1400-1600 cm−1. The absorption band at ∼1455 cm−1 and ∼1540 cm−1 can be attributed to the characteristic pyridine adsorption peak on Lewis acid and Brønsted acid, respectively, and the absorption band at 1490 cm−1 was attributed to both the pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid and Lewis acid [30,38,39]. The appearance of these three characteristic peaks indicated that the aluminum species could be introduced into the KIT-6 framework by solid-phase grinding, with homocrystalline substitution of Si4+ and consequently the active centers were formed. In addition, the relative distribution of Lewis and Brønsted acid on the catalyst surface was analyzed using quantified calculations [20,21,40], and the results were listed in the Table 2 . With the increase of Al content, the amount of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites increased first and then decreased. After introducing 3 wt.% Al into the KIT-6, the Lewis acid and Brønsted acid content were only 49.07 µmol·g−1 and 31.95 µmol·g−1. As the Al content increased, the Lewis acid and Brønsted acid content increased to 93.86 µmol·g−1 and 73.93 µmol·g−1, and the total acid content (Lewis acid + Brønsted acid) increased to 167.79 µmol·g−1. When the Al content increased to 5 wt.%, the Lewis acid and Brønsted acid content decreased, with the Lewis acid and Brønsted acid content decreasing to 39.09 µmol·g−1 and 60.00 µmol·g−1, and the total acid content (Lewis acid + Brønsted acid) decreasing to 99.09 µmol·g−1. However, the B/L acid ratio gradually increased with the increase of Al content, from 0.65 at 2 wt.% to 1.53 at 5 wt.%. It was obvious that the acid type distribution of K-xAl catalysts could be adjusted according to the content of doped Al, and K-4Al had the highest Lewis acid and Brønsted acid content. Although the K-5Al possessed the highest B/L acid ratio, the low Brønsted acid content made it doomed not to have too high catalytic activity [20,21]. Except for the kinds of acid sites, the acid strength was also essential for the GVL decarboxylation reaction. Hence, NH3-TPD was conducted to study the acid strength of K-xAl catalysts [10,15]. According to the literature, the catalyst acid sites are divided into two types. The weak acid sites are in the temperature range of 150 ∼ 300 °C for the desorption curve, and the strong acid peaks correspond to the desorption curve above 300°C [41]. The Fig. 7 gave the NH3-TPD profiles of the K-2Al, K-4Al and K-5Al catalysts. In the spectra, each catalyst showed significant desorption peaks in the temperature range of 150 ∼ 250 °C. Among them, the K-4Al catalyst showed the largest peak area, indicating that K-4Al had the highest weak acid content. The weak acid content on the surface of this catalyst was calculated to be 0.31 mmol·g−1. K-2Al and K-5Al catalysts had lower weak acid content, which was 0.10 mmol·g−1 and 0.20 mmol·g−1, respectively. The amount of weak acid increased first and then decreased with the increase of Al species, which was in accordance with the results obtained from 27Al NMR and Py-FTIR. 3.3 Catalytic active test and reaction conditions optimization 3.3.1 The effects of Al content on the catalytic performance When aluminum species were introduced into KIT-6 by solid-phase grinding, different Al content had a strong influence on the surface acidity of K-xAl catalysts, and the corresponding catalyst exhibited different catalytic activity. The Fig. 8 showed the catalytic activity change of GVL to butene over K-xAl catalysts at 300 °C and specified reaction conditions. For the pure KIT-6 catalyst, hardly any catalytic activity was found, as its surface did not have any solid acid sites, which again suggested that the solid acid sites played the role of active sites for the GVL decarboxylation process. When 1 wt.% Al was introduced into the KIT-6, the butene yield rapidly increased to 54.2%. The butene yield showed a “volcano” trend with the increase of Al content. When the Al content reached 4 wt.%, the butene yield reached the highest value of 90.1%. However, when the Al content was as high as 5 wt.%, the butene yield decreased to 81.6%. This variation trend of catalytic activity of K-xAl catalysts was highly consistent with the analysis of catalyst structure and surface acidity. Under the same conditions, the K-4Al catalyst with a suitable B/L acid ratio and a large number of weak acid sites exhibited the best catalytic performance. When the Al content was too low, the catalyst could not produce enough acid sites for the decarboxylation reaction, while when the Al content was too high, aggregation of aluminum species outside of the framework led to a reduction in the number of exposed acid sites. Also, the catalytic activity of pure alumina for this reaction was tested as a comparison. Under the same reaction conditions, pure Al2O3 that only had Lewis acid sites on the surface was obviously not efficient in catalyzing the preparation of butene from GVL, with butene yield below 30% and GVL conversion of 88.8%. It further emphasizes the importance of both Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites during the reaction process. Moreover, it can be found that the conversion of GVL can easily reach above 85% in the presence of solid acid sites on the catalyst surface, which indicated that the ring-opening of GVL was easy to happen, as reported by our previous studies [21]. 3.3.2 Reaction conditions optimization of K-4Al catalyst In the process of research and development of any thermocatalytic reaction, it was desirable to obtain satisfactory catalytic activity under the conditions of the shortest reaction time, the lowest reaction temperature, and the least amount of catalyst. On the basis of the above results, the best catalyst K-4Al was selected to optimize the reaction conditions. The heat provided for the reaction was one of the high energy consumption factors in the catalytic reaction process. Fig. 9 (A) exhibited the schematic diagram of the catalytic activity of the catalyst with the reaction temperature. It can be observed that the butene yield increased gradually with the increase of the reaction temperature. When the reaction temperature was 260 °C, the butene yield was only 43.8%. When the temperature reached 300 °C, the butene yield reached a higher value of 90.1%. As the temperature further increased to 320 °C and 340 °C, the butene yields increased to 94.3% and 96.1%, but the increase did not exceed 5%. The temperature rise had a positive effect on the GVL decarboxylation reaction, but the higher reaction temperature greatly increased the energy consumption. Therefore, the reaction temperature of 300 °C was selected as the best reaction temperature under the premise of ensuring the yield of butene. Fig. 9(B) showed the trend of catalytic activity as a function of reaction time. When the reaction temperature was 300 °C and the catalyst dosage was 10 wt.%, the butene yield of the reaction gradually increased with the prolongation of the reaction time within 270 min, from 71.9% at 180 min to 91.3% at 270 min. Nevertheless, when the reaction time was 240 min, the butene yield reached 90.1%. The continuing reaction of another 30 min only brought a 1.2% increment in the butene yield. Further increase in the reaction time did not lead to a significant increase in the butene yield. When the reaction time was further extended to 300 min, the butene yield decreased to 89.0%. This might be due to the yield of some by-products increasing with time, which in turn led to a decrease in butene selectivity. Hence, from the point of view of economy and reactivity, the reaction time of 240 min could be regarded as the best reaction time. Fig. 9(C) gave the trend of catalytic reaction activity with the catalyst dosage. At the reaction temperature of 300 °C and the reaction time of 240 min, the butene yield increased in a stepwise manner with increasing catalyst dosage. The butene yield was 78.2% with the addition of 6 wt.% catalysts relative to the mass of GVL. As the catalyst dosage increased to 8 wt.% and 10 wt.%, the butene yields increased to 86.5% and 90.1%. However, with the further increase of the catalyst dosage to 12 wt.% and 14 wt.%, the butene yield did not improve significantly. 10 wt.% catalyst could meet the requirements of the GVL decarboxylation reaction, so the optimal catalyst dosage was selected relative to the GVL mass of 10 wt.%. In conclusion, the butene yield of K-4Al obtained by a simple solvent-free solid-phase grinding method could be enhanced to 90.1% under the reaction conditions of 300 °C, 4 h and 10 wt.% catalyst dosage. Herein, the comparison of the K-4Al catalyst with those reported in the literature for GVL decarboxylation to butene was also summarized and presented in the Table S1. From the table, it can be found that although some catalysts are slightly better than K-4Al catalyst in catalytic performance, the simple synthesis process, without the use of any solvent and efficient production of butene for K-4Al catalyst, which made it more potential for further practical industrial production. 3.4 Kinetics studies For GVL decarboxylation, researchers generally agreed that the decarboxylation of γ-valerolactone to butene was composed of GVL ring opening and γ-protonated PEA decarboxylation [10,11,13,15,19–21]. The process of ring opening of GVL required low active energy and occurred rapidly, and the rate-controlling step was the decarboxylation reaction of γ-protonated PEA to butene for the whole reaction [21]. Based on the above conclusion, the rate constant of the GVL decarboxylation reaction was calculated by plotting the curve with the logarithm of the amount of protonated pentenoic acid as the vertical coordinate and the reaction time as the horizontal coordinate, as shown in the Fig. 10 . The linear relationship between the reaction time and the logarithm of the amount of protonated pentenoic acid in the graph was good, which was consistent with the first-order kinetic model (Fig. 10(A)). At a low temperature (280 °C), the reaction rate constant was low, and the reaction gradually became easier as the temperature increased. The reaction rate constant was 1.16 × 10−2 min−1·g−1 at 300 °C. When the temperature reached 320 °C, the reaction rate constant was 1.67 × 10−2 min−1·g−1 (Table 3 ). Subsequently, the active energy ( Ea) of the reaction was calculated according to the Arrhenius equation, which was 91.41 kJ·mol−1 (Fig. 10(B)). 3.5 Regenerable performance of the K-4Al catalyst For heterogeneous catalysts, regenerative cycle ability was one of the most important advantages. In actual industrial production, the regeneration stability of multiphase catalysts was even more critical for economic and environmental reasons. In this part, the regenerable performance of the K-4Al catalyst (six catalyst cycle tests) was evaluated at 320 °C, as shown in the Fig. 11 . From the figure, it can be found that when the reaction temperature was 320 °C and the fresh catalyst was tested for the first time, the butene yield was 94.7%. Although there was a slight decrease in butene yield as the cycle test continued, the butene yield could still remain at 92.2% after the sixth cycle test, and the butene yield decreased by only ∼2.5%. In addition, the GVL conversion rate was consistently above 96% in six cycles. In order to compare the changes in structure and acid amount of the catalysts before and after the reaction, TEM and NH3-TPD tests on the K-4Al catalyst after three times reactions were performed, and the results were shown in the Fig. 12 . From the TEM image of fresh and spent K-4Al catalyst (Figs. 3D and 12A), it can be found that the mesoporous structure of the catalyst was largely retained after several reactions. However, some shadows still appeared, which may be guessed to be the post-reaction organic matter that had not been completely removed, or some destroyed structure of KIT-6 support by high activation temperature. In addition, the acid amount variation of solid acid catalysts was an important indicator for the study of catalyst regenerability. As shown in the Figs. 7 and 12B, the NH3-TPD characterization and the acid amount data effectively demonstrated that the K-4Al catalyst had a sufficient and stable acid amount, and was still able to reach 0.29 mmol·g−1 even after three reactions with only a small decrease in acid amount. The excellent regenerative stability of K-4Al and its unique acidic site were closely linked. Combined with the TEM characterization, the higher activation temperature (600 °C) removed most of the organic matter from the catalyst structure, while the high temperature beyond the synthesis temperature led to the collapse of a small part of the catalyst structure. This was the reason why the peak of the catalyst after several reactions in NH3-TPD shifted toward the higher temperature. The experimental result and characterization results indicated that the K-4Al catalyst possessed satisfactory regenerable performance under the given reaction conditions, which was expected to be applied in further practical industrial production. 4 Conclusions In this study, a highly active K-4Al catalyst for catalyzing GVL decarboxylation to butene was prepared by a simple and economical solid-phase grinding method. The research found that the introduction of Al species was both embedded into the KIT-6 framework and dispersed on the surface of the catalyst without destroying the original ordered mesoporous structure. Due to the introduction of Al species, a large number of weak acid sites as well as Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites were generated, which were essential for the decarboxylation of GVL to butene. Under the reaction conditions of 300 °C, 0.1 MPa pressure, 4 h reaction time and 10% catalyst concentration, the K-4Al catalyst could achieve a 90.1% yield of butene. The active energy of the GVL decarboxylation to butene reaction over the K-4Al catalyst was also calculated by kinetic study, which was about 91.41 kJ·mol−1. In addition, the K-4Al catalyst also had excellent reproducibility. After six cycles of tests, the K-4Al catalyst still retained the basic mesoporous structure and contained a large number of weak acid sites. The butene yield could still remain at 92.2% after the sixth cycle test, and the butene yield decreased by only ∼2.5%. coredata.dc:description: This work aimed at elucidating the beneficial effect of the solid-phase grinding method on the catalytic performance of K-xAl for catalyzing γ-valerolactone to butene. Research indicated that a part of Al species was successfully introduced into the framework of KIT-6 support without destroying its original ordered mesoporous structure by the solid-phase grinding treatment method. Hence, Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were formed on the surface of the catalyst. By adjusting the amount of Al species, the content of weak acid sites (100-300 °C) on the catalyst surface can reach as much as 0.31 mmol·g−1. Through the catalytic activity tested, the K-4Al catalyst exhibited optimum catalytic performance. The GVL conversion rate and butene yield can reach 96.2% and 90.1% at 300 °C, respectively. In addition, the K-4Al catalyst also showed satisfactory renewable performance in cycle tests. These findings will provide useful guidelines for further catalyst design for the preparation of butene from γ-valerolactone.
coredata.dc:title: Fast synthesis of K-4Al catalyst with acid sites for catalyzing biomass-derived γ-valerolactone to butene
